QuestionStem: Explore the images to learn about energy transfers that occur as water changes state.

images.caption: As air temperatures increase, the water molecules in this ice begin to vibrate just enough to break free and start to flow past one another to form a liquid.
images.altText: This photograph shows drops of water melting off icicles.

images.caption: As air temperatures decrease, the molecules in liquid water begin to move more slowly until they only vibrate in place. The molecules form the rigid structure of solid water, or ice.
images.altText: This photograph shows a lake beginning to freeze.

images.caption: As air temperatures increase, liquid water molecules vibrate enough that some will escape the liquidâ€™s surface into the air above as water vapor.
images.altText: This photograph shows a serene lake on a warm day.

images.caption: As water vapor molecules rise, they eventually enter colder air. This causes the molecules to vibrate at a slower rate and change to liquid water droplets.
images.altText: In this photograph, white fluffy clouds form against a bright azure sky.
